text: Peter pan needs a¬†real movie done right with an artistic vision.¬† It needs to¬†have ¬†that magical, Dreams are real if you believe¬†"Hook" feeling, But¬†still dark¬†with a¬†new aged¬†realistic feel to it as well. It needs to be¬†epic, yet ¬†not all action and cartoony c.g.i. over the top bullshit. ¬†It needs to be¬†¬†well written, well acted and take itself¬† seriously. They need to stick very close to the story and not add drastically to it. J.M Berry¬†¬†¬†wrote a beautiful story about a lost boy who never grows up.¬†Who fights pirates and flirts with mermaids and¬†kicks it ¬†with Indians. His side kick is an¬†ancient fiery with ¬†a school girl¬†crush who makes it so he can fly.¬†Together they have endless adventures and fight epic battles. No rules,¬†No¬†getting old and selling out.¬† Its any young boys perfect¬†dream world.¬†But with the right moral's, Cause in the end He falls in love and decides to grow up after all. At least that's my favorite version of the story and the one I would go with. But if your going to do a movie ¬†¬†Make us fall in love with the characters as well as the story. I didn't like ¬†hooks appearance in the trailer Hook¬†who is sposed to be the ultimate¬†villainous foe of Peter Pan. I don't see him ever looking like that actor. Plus I did not like¬†the fact that tiger lily was white. I am sure they will play with that story line. ¬†The way¬†Hugh Jackman was playing black beard is the kind of hook I want to see.¬†I¬†would cast Daniel¬†Day Lewis for Hook. But if you want to do a cool origin story black beard¬†could be a decent¬†add on. But will see.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†

text: Just to be clear, I was opposed to Michael B Jordan playing Johnny¬†Storm in the Fantastic Four just like I was opposed to Jessica Alba playing Susan Storm because she is a Latina and she looked very fake¬†the more¬†they tried to make her white for that role. So not all "black people" are okay with blacks taking very known white roles especially us comic book and DC fans. I'm still pissed about Amy Adam's pasty ass¬†playing¬†Lois Lane.  Also, when you reference Annie and the actress portraying her (being black) that's when you're out of line. Everyone knows that kid movies and programming is off limits. Are you this equally upset with HBO's Happily Ever After series? Are you upset with Brandy's portrayal of Cinderella? No and this is because you should want to teach you children that color doesn't matter but that is NOT what you're teaching your kids. So now you're bringing this shit up to offer a tiff for tat because there is no other possible explanation for the blatant disregard of Tiger Lilly being white! text: Okay, I consider myself an optimist. I tend to think of a movie I see a trailer for being good until I see it and know that it's bad. But this just raises too many flags. ANOTHER origin story? Ick. Blackbeard, a historical character who actually lived being in a fairytale he has never been a part of before (correct me if I'm wrong on this, I'm actually not sure)? Ick. A young, heroic and pretty Captain Hook who in no way resembles any version of Captain Hook we have seen before, and has the name Hook before he even has a Hook? Ick. And a WHITE Tiger Lilly? Triple ick. Atleast in Lone Ranger, they atleast TRIED to make Johnny Depp look native American.  Hugh Jackman looks like the only saving grace of this movie, and as much as I love him, I think I'll pass.

text: ¬† So...THIS is Hook's REAL back-story but this is ironic because the movie is titled "Pan" and the already-existing movie titled "Hook" was actually a continued later-in-life sequel to the story about one of Robin Williams' adventures and NOT actually about Hook and then there was supposedly a [shitty as usual] remake of Peter Pan released over a decade ago that should have been Peter's back-story and therefore titled "Pan" but here we now have yet another shitty movie which is actually the origin story of BOTH these characters (finally) but it is wrongly titled "Pan", which should have been the title of the last movie.  I shall now conclude that this movie's title should have been: "X-Men Origins: Hook and Pan"  Another futile attempt to revive this boring, dead, and ridiculously uninteresting story. text: This idea could work if three things are done 1. Tell us nothing about his Mother. We don't need an Amazing Spider-Man opening with her being a spy or taken away because there are forces at work we do not understand. Just leave it at she wanted him but couldn't take care of him.  2. Do not make Hook his father. In fact don't make Hook related to or connected to Pan at all. Every incarnation tries to do this and the only one that has ever done this well is the miniseries Neverland (in fact save yourself the money and just find Neverland online). He's not his father, uncle, cousin. He and Peter have never known each other before this.  3. Keep it short. And by that I don't just mean keep the runtime short I mean don't do what Maleficent did. Don't keep a lot of filler in while we wait for the story to take hold. Have the setup be short and get them to Neverland quick, run into hook, setup the plot and finish it up in, at most two hours.  If they keep these restrictions we'll have a good fun movie to watch this summer

text: The only thing that may redeem this movie may be Hugh Jackman. But seriously. I am so tired of all those remakes, origins and shit. It's just another way of making more money. I'm sorry, but as a huge fan of the Peter Pan stories and original movies, I feel really bad. And why do they try to make this badass?? It's a children's tale!!! It's like the Hobbit!!! Don't get me mistaken, Tolkien is my favourite person on Earth and I love his books more than anything, but the Hobbit is a children's book. They did a better job at making it and it's not so bad, but it's barely a shadow of LOTR. I'm just fed up with the money-making machine that is Hollywood. I agree that a lot of stuff is really good, but please, stop making these movies that really aren't cinema. Please.

text: I don't know if I will see this. I used to be a big fan of Peter Pan. I loved Hook and most of the other versions of the story. It as ruined for me when I final actually read the original Peter Pan. The character of Peter was a total sociopath. He would force the Lost Boys to play game in which he would murder them, and to him their lives meant nothing. Hook was, interestingly enough, a much more moral character. Yes he as a pirate, and yes and was trying to kill Peter. However, he was very conflicted over the idea of killing a child, and was only going to due it because, against for his amusement, Peter and the Lost Boys would randomly attack and kill his crew. As for the Indians, he was their ally only because at that time he was having more fun fighting pirates. He would also attack the Indians sometimes. In fact, I read that originally, Hook was not even going to be in the story. It Peter himself was going to be the bad guy. The story was not about the magic of childhood. It was about how vicious children can be to each other, and why adults must watch out for children. Anyway, this kind of ruined Peter Pan for me. I might see this new one, but only if I hear it is good.

text: So many problems with this. 1. Why are all the tribe members white? 2. Why does the tribe don outfits that look like an exploded children's craft fair? 3. Where does Tinkerbell arrive? 4. Wtf is with the industrialization of neverland?? 5. ^Again, what is with the miners? Looking back to previous movies AND the original story there are NEVER that many inhabitants. 6. Where's the magic? Fairies?? Hello??? This movie is unnecessary. In the original story we ALREADY have an explanation as to how Peter and the other boys got to neverland. Upon hearing his parents talk about his future, peter runs away to the gardens of Kensington palace in London where he meets the fairies who take him away. The lost boys were babies who rolled away from their mothers in strollers. Goodbye.

author: Catnut

text: How many "untold stories" do we need to have Hollywood? For once, can't you just admit that it's another adaptation. The moment they say "untold" (unless it is based on the original source material) it is almost as though they are denying the real story. It's almost heart wrenching whenever the story would suddenly become something like a deconstruction of its original tale when they claim it as "untold". Adaptation, yes, I would accept. "Untold story" is almost a no-no unless the writer him/herself would admit to the tale. Forgive me. I am just a little bit over the past adaptations of so many stories that tries to go for the deconstruction method of its own source material
author: TheSingingBUn

text: It'll be interesting to see how they spin it.Thinking outside of the box (seeing as it is an retelling of a story never told but is familiar, not really a prequel to the source material) I'm reminded of the concept of how stories are changed, skewed as they are passed through time - maybe that's the liberty and stance that movie makers take? ¬†Disney did this in animated forms with other versions of fables, folk and fairytales, all of which were actually horrid. Shakespeare took such liberties in his time with his plays... it's really nothing new. Maybe they're posing the question ¬†- Ok so "what if", it doesn't take away from the original, because as many of you have made it clear (some even quoting Hook as the best... err... I loved it too, but really?) the originals still stand heads above the rest. If anything, the original book will be reprinted (though it never has been out of print) "GOSH" will get some money for the rights - but not as much seeing as this is a deviation. All in all this is still a business, and it's tiresome - but I think this will actually be decent.¬†

text: Personally, I think it will be an enjoyable twist on the original tale. Peter Pan has one of those stories that is fun no matter how it's interpreted. For example: Hook, Neverland, and Season 3 of Once Upon a Time (by far my favorite season of the show). These are all origins, sequels, and spin-offs yet are completely different from one another, the only similarities are the characters. Even when the actual story is being told it can be completely different. There's Disney's Peter Pan and then there's Peter Pan (2003). It will still be one of my favorite fairy tales

When I first heard about this I was like "Oh come on they're doing another Peter Pan movie after that live one in 2004, even the Disney cartoon was still better, despite the racists part with the Native American's look and song" What I didn't know is that this is a origin story, a concept similar to Steven Speilberg's classic adaption to make an original sequel, "Hook" where Peter Pan has grown up and forgotten himself but here we witness his beginning. Though this concept gets pretty old, two friends meet and eventually become enemies as seen here that Hook is a ally. I'm not sure if it's good or bad, I don't know. For example: live fairy tale films such as Disney's Wonderland: too much Tim Burton weirdness & terrible visuals. Oz :good visuals & story, but needed better actors. Maleficent: too centered on making the good ones bad, but pretty good dark look & Jolene pulls it off well. I'm already assuming Cinderella next year will have mixed results too anyway. I might just see it at home or see it with my sister since she has the entire collection of peter pan movies, like "Finding Neverland". Overall this looks interesting but I won't try to set my hopes too high you know.¬†
author: Shaheer Chowdhury

author: Mariano Castillo

text: People act like this is the first Peter Pan origin story ever done but honestly it isn't and it doesn't really feel that original?? The book series Peter and Starcatchers (which is amazing) has been out forever and it has it's own award-winning Broadway play completely dedicated to the beginnings of Peter Pan. Not to mention the casting of--holy shit--POC actors for POC characters. Sorry, Rooney Mara, but I laughed when I saw you in that Tiger Lily costume--you could not be more unfit for the role. I understand you're an accomplished actor and I respect you for that--but I /don't/ respect you for taking a role that you had to understand was a whitewash. (And speaking of that, the Mollusk tribe in the book is treated with a beautiful kind of respect and uniqueness--not this ridiculous over-done playing-on-stereotypes portrayal of what feels like the 1800 perspective of what "native tribe" means.)¬† I could be wrong. This is, after all, only the teaser trailer. Maybe this movie will redeem the fuck out of itself leave us all weeping politically correct tears. But factor in a casting screwup worthy of a 69,000-signature petition imploring Warner Brothers to cut the bullshit, and a roster of starring roles whiter than the teeth of any Disney Princess--and hope for redemption is about as likely as a non-pretentious JJ Abrams film.  tl;dr: not impressed.¬†  (am curious about Levi Miller, though!)

text: To all the people bitching that Rooney Mara is "too white", your ignorance sickens me. If this was a historical account or any work on non-fiction I would agree, BUT IT'S NOT! The role of a native American is rarely played by them in movies. Can you name ONE Native American actress that has the same acting ability as Rooney Mara? This is a work of fiction and if you get mad because someone is "too white", YOU are the racist.

text: I hope this movie becomes the laughing stock of the remakes. First of all, being a Native American myself, I find it highly disrespectful that they would cast a white woman as the chief's daughter, and recognize I said chief's daughter since the line of monarchy did not and has never existed in Native American culture, that was the European's mistake that has stuck throughout history for some stupid reason. Second, what the fuck is up with the tribe's costumes? They look like something out of a Katy Perry music video. If you're going to do Natives, then fucking do them right! Warner Brothers, I really wish, like the 2003 version of Peter Pan, you also had the decency to cast an actual Native American woman as Tiger Lily. America needs to stop with this white washing bullshit when it comes to people of Native American descent. Also, I think your calms of "multi-racial" is a load of shit, and that this is just pure laziness. I hope this movie bombs in the box office, or better yet, I hope people protest against its release. Fucking disgusting!

text: 1. In the original Peter Pan books, Tiger Lily is canonically Native American. She, and her tribe are described as "redskins", which translates to American Indian for all of those who use the excuse "Neverland isn't Native American". 2. Rooney Mara was not chosen "simply out of talent". Native American women did audition but were explicitly told that the producers were not looking for Native Americans to play Tiger Lily. They were looking for a white actress. All Native Americans that sought to audition were turned away without being given a chance. 3. If you're going to argue with the backlash Disney's 1953 Peter Pan received due to their awful portrayal of Native American's, let me point you towards Universal Pictures' 2003 Peter Pan which used an actress from an Indian Tribe as their Tiger Lily. They didn't receive the backlash you're using as an excuse. 4. For those arguing about the casting of Annie as a black girl, I have a few things; First of all, you're disregarding the fact a Native American was whitewashed with the argument that there's a black girl playing a white character. Hypocritical, much? Secondly, when Annie was first created, her red hair made her appear more vulnerable as a character due to the prejudice against the Irish at the time. Bearing in mind this was in the early 20th century, and I can see why they would use that same vulnerability in the form of a black girl due to the evident prejudice now going on towards blacks in today's society. Thirdly, Annie was first released when over 90% of the population was white. Nowadays, over 50% of orphans in New York are African American, so it makes a lot of sense. 5. The reason people are so angered over this is because there is next to no poc [people of colour] representation in the media. Whenever we get the chance to see a character that isn't white in media, they get replaced by a white actor. This is also why some people aren't as angered over the Annie casting, because it's nice to actually see a black person in media for once (and please don't try saying something stupid along the lines of "we see Will Smith in movies all the time" because he's one of the very few poc in media and by using him as your defense you just sound silly). No matter which poc in movies you try to use as your defense, it's still a fact that more than 80% of main roles in media are given to white people. Yeah, you know that anger you're feeling over Annie being portrayed as a black person? Imagine if that happened almost every single time a white person was given the chance to have a main role in media. Now you might get a glimpse of what it's like for poc. 6. To the person who called out someone for being a racist and then proceeded to use the n-word, you're a disgusting hypocrite and I hope someone teaches you a lesson one day for using such a vile term.
author: lexus

text: First of all, Neverland is a made up island in a completely different world, located at "the first star to the right and straight on 'till morning". So, to say that the indians located there are "Native American" - meaning native to the Americas, which is no where near Neverland - is completely inaccurate. Indian is just an outdated term that was used to describe the tribes that lived in Neverland, if anything you should be calling them Native Neverlandians. The two cultures of Native Americans and Native Neverlandians have nothing to do with each other and should be depicted as such. Now, it seems that that this movie might be attempting to do just that, seeing as the costumes worn show very little similarity to that of traditional Native American wear.  Secondly, if you truly wish to live in a color-blind world, you must accept a person of ANY race playing ANY person they wish to. You must be ok with a black person playing a traditionally white role, a hispanic person playing a traditionally asian role, or anyone of any mixture playing anyone of any mixture. This includes a white person playing whomever they wish.  I understand that you are just trying to be respectful, but please just think about this for a minute before you decide whats right and whats wrong.

text: Even though this is a cash grab movie I still want to see it...and not cuz I like peter pan (personally I dont like the story at all) but because I'm hoping they have hook and pan be friends in it. Its a common story element for prequels to make characters whom we know in the future will be bitter rivals/enemies be friends, until some sort of climatic event shatters their relationship. Its a really good staple in story telling, it gives the characters more depth. We get to see the future villain, back before they fell into the darkness and were still redeemable, and we get to see the hero before they became bigger then life.¬†

text: I like Peter Pan, and I have to say that this looks incredibly stupid as a Pan prequel. ¬†It doesn't fit with J.M. Barrie's much more simplistic vision of how Peter first went to Neverland. ¬†Here, he gets the name Peter Pan because he wears a necklace of a pan. ¬†He befriends Captain Hook before Hook had a hook and became the captain. ¬†Blackbeard (who has no business being here) is inaccurately portrayed by a miscast Hugh Jackman.  According to Barrie's original play, Peter was an infant and overheard his parents talking about what he was to be when he grew up. ¬†He didn't like that, so he escaped from his carriage and ran off. ¬†Starving, the infant Peter cried out and Tinker Bell heard him and rescued him, taking him back with her to Neverland. ¬†That's it. ¬†None of this spectacle.¬†  I'll probably see it around the time it comes to DVD (simply because, as I said, I like Peter pan), but WB can expect nothing from me for this atrocity.¬†

How about using your brains for longer than 5 seconds to come up with an original story and THEN implement the gorgeous graphics in to make something brilliant? text: Does it REALLY matter that they made some characters white? Maybe they didn't specify race in the auditions, and just went with the person that fit the role the best? "No, of course not, they're all racist!" Very often, I've found myself amazed by the fact that people seemingly go out specifically to find racism. It's like some people have to analyze everything, just so they can get a kick out of saying: "Yeah, I'm black, I'm being discriminated here because they changed a race of a character to white! Why did this happen??" Or: "Why did they have to make this character white? There was no need for this!! Wth?!" That's the kind of thing I see a lot of. And I don't think it's right, because every character deserves a role if they fit it, and their race doesn't matter. Do you really think that the people making the films are like: "Lets make everyone white. It'll upset everyone on the Internet, and could result in less people wanting to see it, but we'll do it, just to annoy everyone. Yeah!" I think people just need to grow up a little and focus on the actual content of whatever it is, instead of nitpicking on the races of various roles. It's stupid, and it's kind of against the 'everyone is equal' idea that is widely preached by the same people making the accusations.
author: Blobby Jones

text: This reminds me of the show Neverland,  orphan Peter Pan who becomes friends with Hook at first.  Also there could be many explanations as to why Tiger Lily may have light skin. It seems  that the culture is more from India then Native Americans living in the USA. Since Peter Pan takes place in early 1900s, ordinary British society at the time knew very little about those that lived on US soil. I think its because they were more familiar with asian cultures, and spiritual practices of the east because of British colonization. Tiger Lily and her father may have had ancestors from England that lived in India. They could have decided to practice Indian spirituality. Her father is white and looks like a guru. I'm guessing the movie makers may have thought that calling Native Americans, Indians would be politically incorrect. However the Peter Pan novel calls them Indians, you can't really call them Native Americans in Neverland because nobody at that time period would understand what they are talking about. Tiger Lily kind of looks like a hippy almost

text: Watch the 2003 version of Peter Pan, or the Disney animated adaptation. ¬†They're probably the only accurate and faithful adaptations to the source material you're going to find. ¬†If you really want something to nitpick about, then go watch the 1960's made for tv musical about Peter Pan. ¬†Tiger Lily is played by a blonde-haired, blue-eyed white woman, and not to mention Peter Pan himself is portrayed by a 45-year-old woman. ¬†It's not like it wasn't quality entertainment. ¬†It just wasn't going exactly by the book.

text: Oh my gosh, I'm appalled at every's attitude about Tiger Lily! Could you all get more shallow?? When I found out she was being played by Rooney Mara, I thought "Oh yes.That is freaking awesome!" ¬†Based on her as Lisbeth in Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, I definitely think she'll be able to bring it as Tiger Lily. Then I'm reading all these comments about like 'why is she white?' Like, what?! Have you never heard of a little thing called colorblind casting? There's absolutely nothing wrong with it, and I think you should be ashamed of yourselves. ¬†How would you feel if you were Rooney reading all these things you're writing? If I worked on a film and people were judging me based on my skin, I would feel so objectified. You all have got some nerve...you didn't even give her a chance; the movie hasn't been released! Seriously, I thought the opinions would be reversed. What's next? B*tching about when Mary Martin played Peter because she wasn't a guy? And speaking of that, when I heard Cara Delevingne was in this playing the mermaid the first thought I had was 'Oh my gosh, she would make an awesome Peter Pan!'¬†

text: im seeing a lot of comments about the "white native americans." what about the human torch in the new fantastic 4? he's black now and anyone complaining about him is racist apparently. what about the new Annie movie? shes played by a little black girl. technically, saying a white person can't play the part is racist against white people. in all honestly, i think all races should have equal opportunities to play any part. however, some parts need a certain race to make sense to the story. like a white mom and dad having a Asian child that is biologically theirs but they have no Asian ancestors. as far as i can see, all the "Indians" are the same color. if it was inconsistent, then i would have a problem with it. But something EVERYONE should realize is we are all humans. we are all the same species and we should see each other the same. we should have equal opportunity for all races. everyone should have a chance to become what ever they set their heart to and telling someone they can't play a part because their skin color doesn't work for you is wrong. on another note the story was written by J. M. Barrie over 100 years ago. you want the original? read the book. but understand that everyone is different and over the decades, the original story was retold countless times through many plays and movies. it will never be exactly the same as the original because those retellings are inspired versions of the original. why would someone want to tell someone else's story? they wouldn't be able to say it's their story. by changing a few things they can create something new, fresh and exciting. i don't want every peter pan movie to be the same. why would i want to go see a movie I've already seen? i love the movie Hook because it's creative and thinks outside the original story.

text: Hey I'm a big fan of Peter Pan. ¬†I've read the book and seen as many versions of it as I could and I don't mind that they're making another version. ¬†I'm actually excited about this, because each version expands on different themes. ¬†The 2003 version expanded on the theme of the kiss from the book and the meaning of it. ¬†Hook expanded on loss of childhood. ¬†Once Upon a Time expanded on selfishness, loneliness, and cockiness. ¬†Neverland expanded on the idea of immortality. ¬†I wonder what this version will emphasize.

text: People seem confused by this, so I'll explain. The reason people are upset about Tiger Lily being white is because she was originally written as Native American. Honestly, just look at the trailers on the side of this video! All the leads are white! White people are in the center of power and the center of media. Therefore, when you change a white character to a character of color, you are diversifying the media. It isn't racist because white people star in enough stuff already. There are literally movies still being made with all white casts, but nobody complains about those being racist. It isn't racist because racism is discrimination + power, and power is something minorities do not currently possess.

text: Rooney Mara as Tiger Lily... no. Just no. It saddens me when they take the few characters intended for actors of other races than white and have them played by white actors. In the end though people need to realize that in a diverse country as the USA we do not have as much of a diverse array of actors of other colors in mainstream films. This just reminds me when cinema placed an all white american cast in the movie The House of Spirits when they were supposed to be of Latin descent in south america. The movie was bashed by critics because of this and rightly so.

text: This looks so dumb. The moment i heard that song all of my hope was lost. This should be marketed to families instead of teens! The first minute of the trailer is amazing, but after that it kinda looks like the 2010 Alice In Wonderland movie with the whole prophecy and chosen one shit! If theres one thing this trailer does really well, it's showing of Blackbeard! Hugh did a fantastic performance! Too bad i don't like the direction this movie is taking. I would have liked Pan going on a journey exploring Neverland and meeting al these characters! Not him having to save Neverland and defeat Blackbeard. That could be an ending climax, but that shouldn't be the driving point of the movie. That's like if Frodo would have been the chosen one in LotR. Some characters just don't fit that role! I was really hoping this could be an amazing imaginative movie, but i can almost guarantee this is going to flop.

text: This is for all of those who are asking why Tiger Lily is white. If you've read the imdb, you'd know why.   The casting of the Caucasian actress Rooney Mara as the Native American character of Tiger Lily led to an online petition that urged Warner Bros to stop casting Caucasian actors to play people of color. The casting was accused of whitewashing and the petition originally hoped for 5000 signatures. However, more than 20,000 signatures have supported the accusation.

text: they are making such a big deal out of it omg seriously, ok but now they are blaming rooney mara for whitewashing the character ok I understand fine but tell another movie not to white wash before its in filming, rooney mara fine I get it she wasn't native but she played the role wonderfully and I don't think they could of found a white or black or other race acter to play it better than her, things like complaining about it after the movie has been released is really stupid I¬† would complain about it during filming its really can see the cast on imdb before the movie has been made and then make the issue viral but criticizing actress to extent where she regrets playing the character is just wrong, especially as things as such will affect the wonderful of future projects that could be this includes not having the pan triology continued or even doing the stupid thing by changing actresses (which everyone knows deep inside viewers hate when you see different actresses playing the same character in first and second movie) I agree about hollywoods extensive white washing. but seriously I feel bad for the actress , joe wright said tha doesn't regret hiring rooney mara - of course the only regret was that she wasn't native but other than that I think she was brilliant there other wider issues bigger than this current pan situation like the fact that "straight out of Compton" or any other directors other than the white ones movies were not nominated for an Oscar even though they were exceptionally and way better than any movie this year, that's why a lot of black acters and actresses did not attend the Oscar but attended a separate movie awards event == (I saw on tv yesterday ice cube and snoop dog) peace out nina
